issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters (returns String) and the exercise text expects messageOnRide() to return strings like "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]". However, the solution repository defines the Rideable interface and its implementations with a different signature: messageOnRide(String equipment). This parameter mismatch also contradicts the example usage in Main (commented calls to r.messageOnRide() with no argument). This inconsistency will confuse students about the correct method signature to implement and will cause compilation errors if they follow the problem statement/template examples while using the provided solution implementation.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the Rideable API across all artifacts. Two viable resolutions:

Option A (preferred, matches problem statement): Change the solution to declare Rideable.messageOnRide() without parameters (String messageOnRide()), and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() with no parameter, returning strings like "Riding on Pig Doodle"/"Riding on Seal Clarabelle". This makes the implementation match the UML, the problem text, and the example calls in Main.

Option B (if equipment parameter is intended): Update the problem statement, UML, and template Main usage to include the equipment parameter in the specification and examples (i.e., document messageOnRide(String equipment) and call r.messageOnRide("<equipment>") in Main). Ensure all artifacts consistently show the parameter in the interface and implementations.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) and the template expect a no-argument method messageOnRide():String on the Rideable interface and call r.messageOnRide() from Main, but the solution defines Rideable.messageOnRide(String equipment) and implements the method with a String parameter in Pig and Seal. This signature mismatch (extra parameter) means the same conceptual operation 'messageOnRide' is represented with different method signatures across artifacts, which will confuse students: the template/Main calls the no-arg method, the UML/documentation specifies no parameter, yet the solution requires an argument.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the Rideable interface and its implementations with the problem/template specification. Either:
1) Preferred: Change the solution to declare Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters (String messageOnRide();) and update Pig and Seal to implement the no-arg method returning exactly "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (e.g., "Riding on Pig Doodle"). This matches the UML, the Main usage, and the textual requirement.
OR
2) If an equipment parameter is intentionally required, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main to include the parameter (messageOnRide(String equipment)) and update the sample calls accordingly. Prefer option (1) to minimize changes and match the stated exercise requirements.
